It says use name if it does not evaluate to false.
Things that evaluate to false include, but are not limited to:

childList.text: use name if it does not evaluate to false

text: False
None
Edit Added the link provided by SilentGhost in his comment to the answer.
In python, the or operator returns the first operand, unless it evaluates to false, in which case it returns the second operand.
In effect this will use name, with a default fallback of code if name is not specified.
Fire up a Python console:

code:
>>> name = None
>>> code = 0.1
>>> name or code
0.10000000000000001

text: In case name evaluates to false the expression will evaluate to code.
Otherwise name will be used.
Correct, that idiom take the first value that evaluates to True (generally not None).
Use with care since valid values (like zero) may inadvertently be forsaken.
A safer approach is something like:

code:
if name is not None:
  # use name

text: or

code: name if name is not None else code

text: Yes, to understand that boolean trick I recommend you reading this chapter of Dive into Python:
"In Python, and and or perform boolean logic as you would expect, but they do not return boolean values; instead, they return one of the actual values they are comparing.

childList.text: "In Python, and and or perform boolean logic as you would expect, but they do not return boolean values; instead, they return one of the actual values they are comparing."

text: http://diveintopython.org/power_of_introspection/and_or.html
You've it it roughly correct, but 'null' is not precisely what decides.
Basically anything that will evaluate to false (0, false, empty string '') will cause the second string to be displayed instead of the first.
'x or y' in this sense is kind of equivalent to:

if x: x
else: y
Some console play:
yes basically but Null in python can mean more than one thing (empty string , none ..)
like in your case:

code:
>>> name = 'London'
>>> code = 0.1
>>> name or code
'London'
>>> name = ''
>>> code = 0.1
>>> name or code
0.1000....
